awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Increasing wildfires and the loss of legacy carbon from boreal and tundra ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
This research asks how increasing wildfires will change carbon storage in northern ecosystems. Carbon is in all living things, the ocean, the earth, and the atmosphere. Increasing carbon in the atmosphere has led to climate change, which has had major effects across the globe. One effect has been increasing wildfires in northern ecosystems. In these ecosystems, large amounts of carbon are stored in soils. This carbon can be stored for a long time and is sometimes very old. Wildfires that burn these soils can release this old carbon to the atmosphere and cause more climate warming. This project will determine where and when this old carbon is burning. This information will help us understand how increasing wildfires will affect future climate. It will also help fire managers set priorities for where to fight fires. We will share our results with rural northern communities near our research sites and with citizens and youth of Northern Arizona.

This research will investigate how increasing wildfires will impact the long-term carbon storage of Arctic ecosystems. Arctic ecosystems store over 40% of terrestrial carbon and have historically been considered carbon sinks. This means they store more carbon than they lose to the atmosphere. Carbon in these ecosystems is primarily stored in soils for long periods, sometimes centuries. Periodic wildfires release some soil carbon to the atmosphere. Any soil carbon that escapes burning in a previous fire is called 'legacy carbon.' Due to climate warming, wildfires have increased in frequency and severity in northern ecosystems. More severe and frequent wildfires can combust legacy carbon and shift Arctic ecosystems from a carbon sink to a carbon source to the atmosphere. The main objective of this research is to determine the processes that control legacy carbon combustion. Understanding where and when legacy carbon combustion is likely to occur is essential for predicting how frequently Arctic ecosystems will shift from a carbon sink to a carbon source. These results will benefit global stakeholders, including policymakers, by improving our understanding of the mechanisms through which environmental change affects the global carbon cycle and climate. For regional and local stakeholders, such as fire managers, this research will improve our ability to identify areas vulnerable to legacy carbon combustion to better prioritize management decisions. We will share our results with fire managers by partnering with the Alaska Fire Science Consortium. We will also engage with rural communities in Interior Alaska by hiring a local guide and communicating our research goals, progress, and findings with community members. Finally, we will engage with citizens, particularly youth, of Northern Arizona about Arctic research by participating in our local festival of science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our collaborative research project investigated the impacts of intensifying wildfire regimes on the long-term carbon storage of boreal and tundra ecosystems, and specifically combustion of 'legacy carbon'. Globally, one of the most important functions of Arctic and boreal ecosystems is their ability to sequester and store carbon in the soil organic layer and permafrost over long periods. More severe and frequent wildfires can shift northern ecosystems from a net carbon sink to a source to the atmosphere. This shift can occur when organic soil carbon that escaped burning in previous fires or that has accumulated over centuries, termed legacy carbon, combusts.

At the Woodwell Climate Research Center, we selected appropriate field sites to sample for legacy carbon presence and combustion. Over the course of three field seasons, project partners at Northern Arizona University sampled 555 plots from 185 sites located in 31 distinct fire scars. These data were analyzed to determine pre-fire carbon, post-fire carbon, and combusted carbon pools for soils, trees, shrubs, and coarse woody debris. We found that both total and belowground carbon pools differed by stand age. Older forests had the largest pre-fire, post-fire, and combusted carbon pools. Recent reburns consistently had the smallest pre-fire, postfire, and combusted carbon pools, although the differences were relatively small overall. The team also assessed changes in forest species composition following wildfires, finding that moderate and older stands dominated by spruce before fire largely returned to spruce. In contrast, no younger sites returned to spruce, and almost all these sites experienced regeneration failure.

To test hypotheses about the drivers of legacy carbon presence and combustion, we analyzed 96 soil profiles from 10 independent research groups. We found that legacy carbon was present in almost all the moderate to young sites and in about half the older sites. The probability of legacy carbon being present increased with soil organic depth. Younger sites were also much more likely to lose legacy carbon than older sites. These results highlight that increasing fire frequency will likely erode the resilience of boreal forests to wildfire across the circumboreal.

Our team at Woodwell developed a method to map burned area and wildfire carbon emissions at 30 m, upscaled to 500 m, utilizing 30 m Landsat imagery, a suite of geospatial predictors, and machine learning. We estimated that 2.37 Mha burned annually between 2001 and 2019 over Alaska and central-western Canada (the NASA ABoVE domain), and 2.87 Mha burned across all of Alaska and Canada, emitting 79 plus/minus 28 Tg of carbon per year, with a mean combustion rate of 3.13 kg carbon per meter squared. We also found larger fire years and later-season burning were generally associated with greater mean combustion. Finally, we are continuing a study of the biophysical impacts of short-interval reburns in northwestern boreal North America, given the often large feedbacks to local and regional climate. We evaluated the impacts of short-interval reburning on (1) blue-sky albedo during the late winter and spring (generally the time of greatest climate feedbacks from fire-induced albedo changes) and (2) land surface temperature during the summertime. Initial results indicate that reburn events result in significantly higher snow-on albedo with increasing numbers of reburns, both immediately after a fire and up to at least five years post-fire. However, the spring radiative forcing caused by changes in albedo immediately before and after a fire decreases markedly with number of times reburned. Combined with our estimates of combustion in short-interval reburns, this suggests that reburns will have a greater warming impact on climate compared to mid and long-interval fires. Land surface temperatures are also slightly elevated in short-interval reburns compared to mid and long-interval fires.

Taken together, our results on carbon combustion, post-fire successional trajectories, and legacy carbon combustion indicate that reburning can substantially impact the structure and function of boreal forest ecosystems. Increasing wildfire frequency decreases postfire soil carbon stocks, enhances the vulnerability of legacy carbon to combustion, and results in regeneration failure. These changes can ultimately cause a shift in the long-term carbon storage of these ecosystems; from a net carbon sink from the atmosphere over numerous fire cycles to a net carbon source and warming impact on climate. This collaborative project supported undergraduate students, early-career research assistants, and postdoctoral researchers.
